sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews Tonight, I'm Aram Zaidi and these are the headlines this hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Western leaders from the UK and Poland arrive in Kiev to hold talks with President Zelensky in a show of support to Ukraine as tensions over Russia's troop build-up continue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In Moscow, President Putin talks Ukraine tensions, cooperation and energy supplies with Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Amnesty International says Israel is carrying out the crime of apartheid against Palestinians and says it must be held accountable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Israel rejects the accusation, saying they're divorced from reality.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And a nationwide strike marks one year since Myanmar's military seized power.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: We speak to Human Rights Watch.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: seized power. We speak to Human Rights Watch.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening. The leaders of Poland and the UK are in Kiev to meet with President Zelensky in a show of Western support to Ukraine as tensions with Russia continue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Vladimir Zelensky and Boris Johnson will hold talks later, but ahead of the Ukrainian leader welcomed support his country is receiving from the west including arms shipments from the us and other nato countries britain has pledged over 100 million euros in funding in order to promote energy independence from moscow poland's prime minister marowski will meet with the two as part of three-way talks on security he urged germany to reconsider its energy dealings with russia our dear german partners it is impossible to declare solidarity with ukraine and at the same time sign north stream 2 certification documents this does not correlate by launching north stream 2 berlin is giving giving Putin the weapon he will use to blackmail the whole of Europe. Meanwhile, Russia's President Vladimir Putin is hosting Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban in Moscow. The talks are primarily covering energy supply, but Orban is looking to secure more natural gas from Russia. But the two leaders have also discussed rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Although coming under fire from MEPs for meeting with Putin, Orban said it was necessary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, for more on these talks in both Kiev and Moscow,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: we'll be speaking to our Russia analyst Galina Polinskaya in a few minutes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But first, let's head over to London and talk to our reporter, Taig Enright.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Taig, so I'll come to you first.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson's meeting with President Zelensky to offer support.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But what form is this support going to take?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Hi, Mariam.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, listen, in the first instance, a face-to-face meeting, it does count for something at a time such as this we know that the ukrainian leader is meeting boris johnson and the polish leader and the dutch leader at a later point this week boris johnson saying is he had headed off on this trip that as a friend and a democratic partner the uk will continue to uphold ukraine's ukraine's sovereignty in the face of those who would seek to destroy it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And I think those words, certainly among the most assertive that we have heard from European leaders over this past chapter, I suppose, in relations between Russia and the West, certainly more assertive than Germany, even if cynics here at home suggest that Boris Johnson is merely seeking to distract from domestic political troubles that he's having over his leadership.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But there's money on the table as well, as you mentioned in your intro.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The UK pledging £88 million, that's around 100 million euro, to Kiev to promote stable governance and energy independence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: There's also talk of economic sanctions too, were there to be a Russian incursion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But of course, the question hanging in the air is what the UK would do to come to Ukraine's actual defence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And Boris Johnson's Foreign Minister Liz Truss has already poured cold water in any talk of actual military intervention.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Speaking in the last few days, she said it was very unlikely that British troops would partake in any talk of actual military intervention, speaking in the last few days, she said it was very unlikely that British troops would partake in any ground operations if this, you know, ordeal, this whole debacle came to that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, Tag, you talk about rising tensions, but in trying to diffuse tensions, you know, that really continues tomorrow when Johnson is, of course, speaking to Russian President Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That call was delayed from Monday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So what is Boris Johnson expected to push for?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, I think de-escalation will be on his mind, as it is on the minds of all Western leaders when it comes to this bubbling conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The question is how influential Johnson's voice really is.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: As you point out, this call was supposed to happen on Monday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It was cancelled from the British side because of those same domestic problems that I've been talking about, the calls for Boris Johnson's resignation for lockdowns held in Downing Street or parties held in Downing Street during lockdown.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: London tried to reschedule it for today, for Tuesday, but that was rebuffed by Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And the call, as we now understand, is going to happen on Wednesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I think, though, fundamentally, Moscow has made clear that it sees Washington as its main negotiating partner in all of this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Now, of course, any sanctions, economic sanctions, that the UK might impose would hit Russia, would hit Russians, I should say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: There's an awful lot of Russian money here in London, for example.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Although plenty of critics here of the Johnson government have pointed out that, yes, you can talk as tough as you want about sanctions but there is cynicism about how tough they will actually be when the UK has frequently been accused of sitting on his hands amid accusations that London is a haven for dirty Russian money for dirty for Russian money laundering and indeed there are many Russian oligarchs among Boris Johnson's Conservative Party's biggest donors.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Mariam?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Indeed, there are, Tag.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, Tag, let's now bring in Galina, our Russia analyst.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Galina, good to see you too.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So, Polish and British prime ministers are in Kiev to show support for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But President Putin, of course, has a meeting with the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, where he's discussed Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, indeed, they've discussed Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And at the press conference after the talks, Vladimir Putin for the first time actually has spoken out about what he thinks about the U.S. and NATO written answer to Russia's security demands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: This is something the whole world has been waiting for.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So he said that Russia is carefully analyzing the written responses of the US and NATO and underlined that it was already clear that the fundamental Russian concerns were ignored and those concerns he spoke about, it it was preventing nato from um from going eastwards uh uh from uh uh giving guarantees that ukraine will not be a part of nato that nato will go back to the borders of 1997 and mr putin said that you cannot strengthen a security of one's country uh at the expenses of the others that it is not only the principle of the open door that should work when we talk about the securities and he underlined that he discussed with mr. Aubin the situation in Ukraine and mr. Aubin answered in turn he said that his mission was actually peace keeping and that the European, he said that his mission was actually peacekeeping and that the European Union, he said, did not have any single leader that would want a conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And he proposed to look at the, let's say, Hungarian example.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He said that Hungary is a member of NATO and the EU, but it is friends with Russia, and that the example is that in order to be in good relations with Russia you have to have mutual respect those were actually the first words of both leaders at the final press conference after the talks okay so

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Galina they talked about mutual respect but they've also talked energy Orban we believe wants to secure more gas supplies to Hungary can you tell us more about that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Exactly. The talks actually lasted for five hours, and we can suggest that energy was one of the main topics on the table, because after the leaders said that they are talking about more gas supplies from Russia to Hungary, we are talking about 1 million cubic meters per year and those negotiations will continue. And Mr. Orban underlined that it is really, really important for his country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Both leaders also spoke about the future elections and Mr. Orban underlined that he is intended to win. Mr. Putin said that he, Russia will negotiate with any leader who wins the elections, but underlined that their relation is very, very important. It's their 13th meeting. And of course, for Russia and for Mr. Putin and for Mr. Orban, it was important to underline how good was their relationship. And Mr. Putin was saying you, you know, in an informal way to Mr. obon during several times okay we're going to leave it there but glena and tyke thank you both for your insights thank

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: you so much amnesty international says the practices of the israeli state its policies and laws amounts to apartheid against palestinians in a damning new report Amnesty says Israel maintains an institutionalized regime of oppression and domination for the benefit of Jewish Israelis. Prime Minister Yeh Lepid attacked the rights group saying it's no longer a human rights organization but instead it echoes lies shared by terrorist organizations. We are here today to call on the international community to take resolute action against the crime of humanity being perpetrated in order to maintain the system of apartheid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It is the cruelty of the system, the intricate, evolving administration of control, dispossession and inequality, the incredible detailed bureaucratization upon which that system is predicated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Let's now bring in our correspondent Shona Murray, who's live for us in brussels shona good to see you so this isn't of course um the first report to say israel is carrying out a system of party against palestinians no the the amnesty international report sort of is one of a growing number of human rights organizations which say that the situation for palestinians in the palestinian territories and in israel has met the legal threshold to be described as an apartheid and this amnesty international report is after four years of investigations it's quite a hefty report and it goes into the areas in which palestinians are discriminated against such as the massive seizure of palestinian land and homes the demolitions of of Palestinians' homes, the forcible transfer of Palestinian populations outside of their land in order to make way for illegal Israeli settlements, the unlawful killing of Palestinian protesters, the unlawful detention of Palestinian children, and other areas where there's documentation of Palestinians, where they are deemed to be, quote, the inferior race. So this is quite a comprehensive report from Amnesty International.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And I caught up with one of their lawyers, Eve Getty, today, and I asked her a little bit about what they found.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Israelis can have one type of ID card, which means they can travel anywhere and access all rights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Palestinians can have one of four.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And which type of ID you have decides where you can go and when, what services you can access, have decides where you can go and when, what services you can access and even who you can marry. We've documented cases of Palestinian villages who've been disconnected from the water and electricity supply for years. So families trying to survive on less than 20 litres of water per day, living next door to an Israeli settlement with watered gardens and swimming pools. We spoke to Palestinian families whose children died from preventable diseases or diseases that could have been treated. You know, a two-year-old boy from Gaza who died, Abdul Nasir, in August 2020, while waiting for a permit so he could travel to East Jerusalem for cancer treatment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So in no part of the territory and in no aspect of their lives are Palestinians treated equally to Jewish Israelis. And so Shona Amnesty International also calling for an arms embargo and targeted sanctions on Israeli officials. Is there any international support for this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: targeted sanctions on Israeli officials.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Is there any international support for this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Very unlikely, Mary-Eve, that there will be any support for either of those things necessarily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Obviously, if you look at, for example, the situation in the United States where the support for Israel trumps any sort of calls for justice or equality for Palestinians, here in Brussels it's now impossible to get unity when it comes to any sort of statement against Israel, even if there are reasonable criticisms about disproportionate use of force or the breach of the Geneva Conventions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now, the report also calls for the International Criminal Court to consider investigating whether apartheid is there as part of its investigation into the Palestinian territories and also the use of universal jurisdiction where some countries can individually decide to prosecute those responsible for the apartheid regime. But I think it will be some time before we see any of those things materialising. Mariam?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: All right, Shona, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Mariam.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: All right, Shona, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Right, welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson continues to face pressure over his position following the publication of a report by Sue Gray into Downing Street parties released on Monday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The Met Police have said today that they will not publicly name those who may face fines for attending those events.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The police opened an investigation into 12 parties held under Boris Johnson's watch during the height of the lockdown restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, with us now is Conservative MP Sir Roger Gale,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: who was in Parliament yesterday for that Sue Gray report update.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Mr Gale, Sir Gale, thank you so much for joining us on Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, it was an update that really spoke volumes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: How surprised are you by the alleged breaches of Covid rules at Downing Street?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, because the facts have been released for a long time, effectively, Mariam, I'm not really surprised at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: I think the skeleton report, which is all it is at the moment, has already confirmed what we all really knew before, which is that while the public was locked down and having to obey very strict rules, Downing Street was a law to itself and was doing pretty much what it wanted to do. Are you then also surprised by the number of MPs from within your own ranks who have now spoken out against the Prime Minister following the publication of the Suguay report, especially his predecessor? No, I'm not surprised at all because I think like all other MPs I've been receiving emails, other forms of communication from constituents who are very angry at the way they feel they've been let down by the current Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. And that is why I and a significant number of others, I don't know how many exactly, are calling for a leadership election and a new Prime Minister. The difficulty that we've got at the moment, of course, is that we do face an international crisis what is happening in russia and ukraine is very very serious indeed ought to be top of the agenda ought to be top of the business that the prime minister is conducting and we don't want to impede that so we're all in a very difficult position we want to change but by the same token, we accept that the Prime Minister has a difficult job to do at the moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: He does indeed. Now, you say that we want to change.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Do you also see that there's also a huge damage being done to your own party the longer this scandal goes on?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: I think there is short-term damage to the Conservative Party but we are blessed with a lot of talent within the party. If a leadership election takes place then there are a significant number, probably I should think at least eight Conservative Members of Parliament, any one of whom would be honest and strong and take the country forward. So I'm not concerned about the calibre of whoever might take Mr Johnson's place. What I'm concerned about is the country forward. So I'm not concerned about the calibre of whoever might take Mr Johnson's place. What I'm concerned about is the timing now and the fact that a leadership election does take some time. We don't want to destabilise either our own position in the world or the United Kingdom at a time when all this is going on. There are very serious decisions, particularly as you heard, about Russian money in London, that have to be taken and taken fast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: OK, well, Mr Gale, unfortunately, we've run out of time,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: but thank you so much for joining us on the programme tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thanks, Marianne.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: One year on from Myanmar's military coup and protesters across the country have held a silent nationwide strike.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Their new demonstration comes amid fresh international concern.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Matthew in the Cube has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Twelve months on from that military seizure of power, and this was the scene on the streets of Myanmar.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Cities like Yangon were flooded as many businesses closed their doors in a nationwide silent strike.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: These protesters have long opposed Myanmar's army, which seized power last year and ousted the elected government of leader Aung San Suu Kyi, claiming that their election victory had been marred by fraud.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Since then, hundreds of people have been killed amid a struggle for power in what United Nations experts have characterized as a civil war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Indeed, it was last week that we heard from the military government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: They warned people planning on taking part in that strike that they could still face imprisonment or have their property confiscated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And we've also seen fresh concern from the international community about the situation in Myanmar from the likes of the European Union, the United States and the United Nations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But they themselves have also come under some criticism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Euronews spoke to Human Rights Watch Deputy Director Phil Robertson, and we asked him whether the international response to the military takeover in Myanmar had been effective.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The international reaction has been woefully short of what is needed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I mean, we're talking about over 1,500 people killed, well over 10,000 people detained by this military junta.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We have some sanctions from the E.U. and the U.S., Canada, but it's not enough. Many other countries like Australia, Japan, South Korea, which are major investors in the economy in Myanmar, have done nothing. This is a tug of war between the people of Myanmar and this military junta.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And Mariam, you have other international campaigners who are calling for a stronger response to help and urge the military to free those who have been detained and help return Myanmar on a path to democracy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: a path to democracy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Six decades ago, French creator and designer Yves Saint Laurent launched his first fashion show in Paris.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Such was the extent of his cultural impact.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Saint Laurent was appointed Grand Officer of the Légion d'Honneur by French President Sarkozy in 2002.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, in a city where it all began, organisers are commemorating the life and work of this unique fashion icon. Nila Riley has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: In Paris' prestigious museums, a celebration of a unique talent. On the 60th anniversary of Yves Saint Laurent's first fashion show, the Pompidou Center is giving pride of place once again to the fabled designer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: He drew inspiration from the masters of modern painting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now his work is displayed with theirs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: There are dialogues that are real sources of inspiration for Yves Saint Laurent, such as Braque, Picasso, Matisse and the Art Deco of the 1930s, and to realize how much he belongs to his time, but also heralds the 21st century and how he is part of our present today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A man of his time, Saint Laurent, who died in 2008, was inspired by his contemporaries and his predecessors, he saw his Ouvre as meriting exhibition like other art forms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I think the absolute dream for him was to be exhibited, or for his designs to be in dialogue with those who inspired him or his sources of inspiration.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: What's very moving with these various institutions, whether it's the Louvre, the Pompidou, the MAM, the Picasso Museum, the Musée d'Orsay, is that each institution we had something to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: At the Louvre, too, Saint Laurent is appearing among national treasures.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Six exhibitions in six museums to be discovered in Paris from now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A great tribute to a great icon of fashion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well that's it for the program.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you.
